job_title: Director of Education in Pasadena, MD
pros: I love this company. There is a passion among the leaders and staff to serve the community and those who need quality hospice care. The biggest difference I see from other employers, in my opinion, is the willingness to learn from our performance and always striving to grow and be better. The executive team is connected to the work, they each possess a heart for our company and staff as well as the families we serve. The leaders all desire to support the company as a whole, each bringing their own gifts to the organization. You can really grow and learn here. I’ve gone from the bedside to middle management to senior leader. Highly recommend.
cons: Like all organizations there are gaps in communication here too. The company really tries to have multiple pathways for information like quarterly all staff meetings, newsletters, special group meetings, etc. I think gaps in communication are common to healthcare and exist everywhere.

pros: Colleagues supported one another when requested.
cons: Poor leadership in the executive level and business level. No support provided when requested, Many RNs left within last 90 days.

pros: Culture and Appreciation by Management is changing (improving), they are trying to build a positive work environment in a very competitive field. This is a big focus.
cons: Nursing shortage. We are looking for more clinicians and competing for staff with hospitals, Nursing homes and assisted living.

review_title: An awful experience in the end
pros: Working in the field, the people you meet in the homes (the patients and caregivers and families) are great mostly. Again, if you're in the field, the other people you work with out in the field are also almost always great, personality-wise.
cons: Unfortunately, not all the nurses are properly trained properly to help the dying so the sad part of this job is watching people die in pain and not being able to help them. You would think you could call the management in at times like that but the management is the worse thing of all about this job. I think you can see this by reading the other reviews. They are unresponsive to the needs of the fields. They do play favorites. If they don't like you, they will fire you in the most humiliating way.That happened to several of the people I worked with there - people who had worked there 20 years. They wiped out the experienced and wise chaplain department and left the chaplains that lack heart. They abuse the nurses and ask them to do more than is humanly possible, so they are overworked. They cut out all the grief workshops for the employees, so they are left dealing with their grief on their own. Everyone else in the world admires these workers- the nurses, social workers, aides and chaplains who are on the battle lines helping people die and the management honestly treats them with suspicion, disregard and as though they bring no value. Want this kind of abuse? This is the place to work! Hope you're a Mother Theresa.

pros: Hospice of the Chesapeake is a nonprofit that is careful steward of the funds it raises. They have a strong plan for moving forward to become a leader in the field of hospice and palliative care. Its grief programs are top notch, with dedicated professionals who are constantly seeking to improve and educate. They offer many professional development programs both internally and for the public and other professionals. Technology and facilities are kept current. Volunteers, an integral part of the mission of any hospice, are thoroughly trained and encouraged to participate in numerous free training that staff also can take part in. Vacation time is very generous and leadership is thoughtful and understanding. Quarterly meetings, called Town Halls, keep the staff well informed of the leadership's plans and how employees fit in.
cons: The nature of the business means there is a disconnect between different departments. Health benefits favor single individuals -- family plans are very expensive.

review_title: Promises made and broken, no respect for disciplines other than RNs, horrible management, work employees to death for mi
pros: Caring for the pts and their families, doing funerals. bereavement.
cons: I had to see up0 to 80 pts in the entire county plus drive time, meetings and assessments all in a 40 hour week. My pts and families were horrifyed...that is when I saw them here and there. I had worked for another hospice in Ohio where none of this happened....my clinical manager quit, others did to, and the lunatics were left running the asylum (none of whom had any idea that spiiritual care meant anything. I have been in bed for months trying to recover.

pros:
Pay for the position was above minimum wage and also was much more than most similar positions elsewhere. It's a small-ish organization making it easy to get to know most employees, who are very friendly and usually supportive.  
There are a fair amount of social events within the organization which, really helps, get to know people in the organization and find common hobbies interest with others.
Work-life balance is good and the benefits are not too bad either.
It's a varied position and you get to learn multiple skills and do tasks for a variety of departments regularly.  
This is a really good position if you're new to an office job or need an in-between job.
cons:
Very little, to no, upward mobility. It is healthcare so the majority of the advancement opportunities favor individuals with healthcare experience. The options not directly wanting/requiring healthcare experience are  limited and seem to prefer specialized/specific experience.
The position itself is not very engaging, and there will be a lot of idle time. The work you get needs to be spread out through the week or you need to fill the time with a hobby or professional development. 
The phone side of the position could easily be replaced with an options menu, as most (if not all) calls will just be transferred with no additional engagement. You do not have the tools to provide help to most callers so calls will always be transferred with no more than general greetings before transferring.
